div.p: 1. V. Lamplight.

Mr Wood came—to speak of the building of the tomb, according to the estimate, and the model he had furnished me last Monday, but I had not made out the agreement, and promised to have it ready to morrow. Mr Withington came, and we went into the woods— My brother, my Sons John and Charles, Peter Turner, Isaac Farrar and Antoine went with us. We resurveyed the Lot conveyed by the family of the Savil’s to my father, and took in a point of land beyond the old remnant of Wall, between Owen’s field, and the Wall that bounds the 600 Acres— Peter Turner says it is claimed by Deacon Spear I wished also to have resurveyed the Lot which was sold to me by mistake last year, as the 4: acre Owen lot; but Farrar, the only person who knew the bounds was obliged to leave us, and Mr Withington who is far advanced in years and convalescent from disease, was so much fatigued that I could not urge him to proceed. We returned about four O’Clock in the afternoon—while I was absent Mr Benjamin Bussey had called, and left a draft of his Will— It contains a very extensive grant of property for the Establishment of a Lyceum at Roxbury to bear his name— After my return I had visits from Mr Webster with Mr Walworth, heretofore a member of Congress from the State of New York, and now one of the judges of a State Court—and in the Evening from Mr Willard. Peale of Salem, with Daniel and Thomas Greenleaf— Mr Nathanl. White also called— He lives at the foot of Penn’s Hill in a house adjoining my land; and being pinched for ground, wants to purchase of me a small strip to square off his lot, and build a barn upon it— I promised to go and look at the place and give him an answer on Wednesday.
2. IV. Lamplight— Dedham— Roxbury— Boston— Dined at Jonn. Mason’s— Quincy— Rain.

Henry Wood came this morning, and took with him the agreement which I had drawn up for the building of the Tomb for my father and mother— He had omitted to include the door in his estimate, and took his part of the Deed with him to ascertain what the additional charge will be for it. He is to come and execute the deed on Thursday Morning— Charles went into Boston in the Stage— I went with Antoine to attend the Probate Court, and present for allowance, the fourth account of the Executors of my father’s will; but no Court was held. the judge and Register were both absent, and a man, whom I found at the Office shewed me an advertisement by the judge published a fortnight since in the Dedham Newspaper that he should not hold a Court this month— The Register of Deeds was likewise absent in Boston: but I left with the Clerk of the Courts, to be given the Register to be recorded, the two copies of the Indenture of Agreement, between the Town, and Congregational Society of Quincy, and me, for the building of the Tomb, and the cession to me of the spot on which it is to stand— The Clerk also found upon the files, my father’s Deed to me of the Mount Wollaston farm; dated 23. September 1819— On the 9th. of October of that year, I left this Deed with the Register to be recorded— A few days since I made out a list of my Deeds and vouchers, and discovered that this deed was missing— I had deposited at the same time with it, another deed, from my brother, which I had after it was recorded taken out from the Registry. I had no recollection of the omission to take this— But so it was: and now at the end of eight years, it was found on the Register’s file— I found also the Record of it in his books— This incident shews the importance of keeping a correct list of Deeds, Vouchers and Securities and of revising it from time to time— It shews also the necessity of attention to my own concerns.
From Dedham I proceeded to Boston, stopping at Mr Bussey’s at Jamaica Plains. But he was himself in the City— In Boston, I sent for a Carriage— Called at Mrs Wilson’s, where Charles lodges, and took him up— Dined at Mr Jonathan Mason’s— Mrs Mason, her son Powell Mason, daughter, Mrs Grant sons in-Law Parker and Dr WarrenI. P. Davis, E. Everett, R. Gardner, F. C. Gray, B. Guild, Joseph Hall, Josiah Quincy, D. Webster and T. L. Winthrop were there. After dinner, I sat Charles down at his lodgings—returned to the Exchange, and thence with Antoine in the Chaise to Quincy— It began to rain as I was going this morning to Dedham, and continued a Rain Storm the whole day— Going from Dedham to Boston, it was the whole time driving in my face, and found myself at Boston wet, without change of clothing.

I rode with my brother to Ebenezer and Josiah Adams’s, and viewed the ground near their dwelling where their Land is adjoining upon mine— There is a brook upon which we border, which they wish to have made straight— It is swampy, and was formerly overflowed by the Mill Pond— The fence is now on their land, at some distance from the brook— They wish to have the brook made to run in the direction of the fence; and for me to purchase the land of theirs upon which the brook would then encroach— About an acre and a half of Swamp— But they could not bring themselves to name a price they would ask for the land. We also went to the Pasture grounds behind my houses, at the foot of Penn’s Hill They advised me to sell off the wood from a great part of my land upon Pine Hill; and offered either to buy a pasture of mine adjoining theirs, or to sell me theirs; but could not name a price at which they would either buy or sell— We thence went to Nathl. White’s; then to Henry Hardwick’s—to Harvey Field’s, and again to White’s, where I found Noah Curtis, and Asa French the Surveyor— White is a shoemaker and lives in a house next Northerly to that in which my father was born— But he is much straitened for land, and wants a small strip of mine to square off his yard and give him room to build a barn. The amount was 14 1/2 square rods— I told him he should have it, but he like the Adams’s could not tell what he would give for it; he said, he would let me know in the Evening— Henry Hardwick, and Noah Curtis, both wanted also some of my land and Hardwick wanted me to join in ditching some saltmarsh adjoining upon his. I postponed these matters, not having time to attend to them at present. Harvey Field wished me to remove the Wall upon my Belcher pasture, so as to straiten the road; the effect of which would be to improve the street, and to give him some additional land upon which to build his house. He also wants me to lease to the town, land enough to build upon it a School House—which I readily promised to do— On returning home, I found Mr Benjamin Bussey, to whom I gave back the draft of his Will— Had a long conversation with him concerning it; and concerning his intended bequest for a Lyceum at Roxbury. I told him I would cheerfully act as one of the Trustees; but advised him to name all the Trustees himself— To appoint seven—empower three to act upon the business of the trust, by majorities, and in the event of the death or resignation as a Trustee, to authorise the remaining Trustees to fill his place; but requiring a majority of the whole number to make a choice— I advised further that as the location of the Establishment was at Roxbury, he should appoint three or four of the Trustees residents at that place, or so nearly in the vicinity that they might always at a short notice be able to hold meetings for managing the ordinary business of that trust— And as the disposal of the property was to be permanent, I recommended that he should appoint young men, for some of the Trustees— He said he should make his dispositions accordingly, and that he should appoint as one of the Trustees, Mr Kuhn, his agent and associate in the factory at Dedham— I told him again that I thought an Act of incorporation might become indispensable for the continuance of the trust; and that difficulties in obtaining it might arise from the large amount of real Estate, he intended they should hold: and advised him to consider the
expediency of authorizing the Trustees in case of necessity to sell the real Estate; excepting that, the occupation of which he has secured to his daughter and grand-daughters for their respective lives. He said he thought the object of the trust would be so much approved by the Legislature that no obstacle would be opposed to the act of incorporation and he was peculiarly solicitous for the continuance of his manufacturing establishment at Dedham, as a part of the property of the trust— Mr Bussey had brought with him Horace Holley, a boy six or seven years old, son of the late President of Transylvania University; whom he said his mother wished to obtain at a suitable age the appointment of a Cadet at West-Point. Mr White came in the Evening, and said Mr French had told him I should ask him two dollars a Rod; for the land which he wanted to build a barn upon, and square off his yard— I told him he should have it for that price; and I filled and signed a Deed accordingly— There was an Evening party at Mr Quincy’s, which I attended— I have laid off a small stirp of Land, from the North-west corner of the garden, for a nursery of trees— It has been fenced off, and a gate has been opened into it from the garden— This afternoon I planted in it twenty rows of Acorns, Nuts, Stones, and Seeds— The time for planting was bad and we were much interrupted by the Rain— My Son George, and Antoine were with me— We planted Acorns, of English, and of Black, White, and grey Oaks— Peach, Plum and Cherry Stones. apple, and Pear seeds— Whole Peaches and Apples, and Horse Chesnuts— Also 10. Pennsylvania Walnuts of the last year.
4. IV:15. Lamplight— Boston— Mechanic Association dinner— Medford.

I executed this morning the contract with Henry Wood, for the construction of the Tomb for my father and mother, under the Temple— George and John came to Boston in the Stage. I left Quincy for the Season, and came with Antoine in my Chaise— The Members of the Massachusetts Charitable Mechanic Association, were assembled at the Exchange Hotel, holding a meeting in the large Hall—many of them came and were introduced to me— Between one and two the procession was formed in which I joined; to the Meeting House in Purchase Street, where after a Prayer by Mr Ripley, the minister of that Church, an Address to the Society was delivered by Mr W. Hilliard. Hymns and Anthems occasional were sung— And we went again in Procession to the dinner at Faneuil Hall— Lieutenant Governor Winthrop, D. Webster, B. Gorham, E. Everett, Dr B. Waterhouse, and a few others were invited as guests— The President of the Society is Mr Armstrong— After joining in the regular toasts, and giving in return for that with which they complimented me—“The American Mechanic. Invention in the Head— Skill in the Hand; and Benevolence at the Heart”—and hearing several Songs, Sentimental and humorous—one of them excellent by Charles Sprague I withdrew, returned to the Exchange Hotel; and as it rained, sent for a Carriage, and came out alone to pass the night with Mr Peter C. Brooks at Medford— I found here only Mr and Mrs Brooks, and their Son Gorham— Abigail is in Boston— I spent an hour this Evening before I retired to bed, in reading and assorting Letters received. The two months I have passed at Quincy and in this Neighbourhood have afforded me some relaxation from excruciating cares and sorrows— But they have not enlivened my hopes of the future. For many years a gracious Providence has dealt with me more in grace and mercy than I have dared to hope. The last years of my life are hurrying on— My health decaying— My public character and reputation assailed by a base and formidable conspiracy, and all my hopes of comfort in private life at the mercy of the most high—
5. V:30— Candle light— Boston.

I wrote about two hours by candle light and after breakfast came into Boston with Mr Brooks in his Carriage. His Son Gorham was with us— Had some conversation with them upon the subject of the Stock in the manufacturing companies existing and projected. They have no favourable opinion of them— From the moment when I alighted at the Exchange Hotel until 2. P.M. I had a succession of visitors— Eliphalet Hale, applies for an appointment as a purser in the Navy— He produced several recommendations of himself, and three Commissions to his father dated in 1775, 1776 and 1777. as Major, Lieutt. Coll. and Coll. in the Revolutionary Army— He was much agitated, and distressed, even to shedding of tears, for which he apologized, but without explanation; leaving me to conjecture the cause— I referred him to the Navy Department for his application, assuring him of my own favourable disposition to him— Mr Ammidon brought me a Translation of an Edict by the Viceroy of Canton in China— It is an answer addressed to the Hong Merchants to a Letter obtained by this Mr Ammidon, through the intervention of Jonathan Russell in 1822. from the Department of State— A claim of indemnity upon the Chinese Government for the alleged plunder by Chinese Subject, of an American Vessel, wrecked on that Coast in 1813. Ammidon said that the chief of the Hong Merchants, had been extremely reluctant in transmitting to the Viceroy the Letter from the Department of State— That he had finally taken it, and the next day, delivered this paper, as the answer of the Viceroy. This answer he said was insulting; but he believed it had been fabricated by the chief of the Hong Merchants himself, and that the Letter from the Department of State to the Viceroy had in fact never been transmitted to him— Mr Holmes was going with his wife to pay a visit to his family in Plymouth County— He spoke of his two successive disappointments in losing the elections first as Senator, and then as a member of the House of Representatives, and in both cases he said by the treachery of his friends— Coll. Apthorp called in the morning, and asked a particular interview, for which I assigned four in the afternoon— He then came, and enquired whether any hope could be entertained that the British Government would ever make indemnity for a cargo of a vessel seized in their own Ports at the beginning of the late War: I assured him they would not, and informed him of what had been done, first at Ghent; then by me in England; and finally through the Department of State—upon that subject. Mr Taylor came with his Son, for whom he wishes to obtain the appointment of a Midshipman in the Navy— I advised him to make the application in writing; which he afterwards did by a Letter— Mr Fuller cautioned me against the appointment of W. Clagget as District Attorney; though he had joined in the recommendations of him— He has been enlightened by Mr Salma Hale— I gave a sixth and last Sitting to Mr Harding; who finished my portrait— Dined at Mr Cruft’s, with Coll. Pickman, and T. Smith, his brothers in Law— In the early part of the Evening visited with him at Mr Patten Hall’s, where with his wife and Sons we found Mr Isaac Smith— Afterwards at Dr Welsh’s where we saw Miss Harriet— The Doctor is gone to Wiscasset— The close of the Evening, I passed at my lodgings— Partly with Mr Webster, in conversation upon public affairs; and the remainder with my Son George, discoursing upon his prospects and purposes. It was past one in the Morning when he left me to my thoughts and to repose.
6. V. Princeton— Mr Boylston’s.

Between 6 and 7. this morning, I left the Exchange Hotel at Boston, in a Carriage, and one pair of horses, hired of O. Gragg, for eight days, at seven dollars a day—accompanied by my Son John and Antoine Michel Giusta— The driver was not acquainted with the road, and went upon the Worcester Turnpike— We had reached Framingham, before I discovered the mistake. We soon after turned off the Turnpike, and came through Westborough, and Southborough to Lancaster—lengthening the distance of our road about seven Miles— It rained when we left Boston, and continued to rain till past Noon—then cleared off— We dined at Davis’s Inn, at Lancaster— While I was there Mr William Stedman called upon me; to recommend Joseph Hooper of Newbury-Port; for some appointment in the Custom-House— Says he has ten children. I remember him as a boy, about that number of years old, when I boarded at his mothers in Newbury-Port, and have not seen him since— We reached Mr Boylston’s at Princeton, about 6 in the Evening; and found him somewhat recovered from a very violent illness which about six weeks since it was thought he would not survive even to this time. He can now rise from his easy Chair, and walk across the room, but cannot go out of the house— He received us with all his wonted cordiality.
7. V:15. Candlelight.

Heard Mr Clarke in the Morning from 1. John 1.1. “That which was from the beginning, which we have heard, which we have seen with our eyes which we have looked upon, and our hands have handled, of the word of life; 2. For the life was manifested, and we have seen it, and bear witness, and shew unto you that eternal life, which was with the father, and was manifested unto us.”— In the afternoon his discourse was from Leviticus 11.44. “For I am the Lord your God: ye shall therefore sanctify yourselves, and ye shall be holy; for I am holy.”— There were six children baptized; four of one family of different ages— The eldest apparently eight or nine years old the youngest three or four— The other two were infants from nine months to a year old. The Congregation was very thin; part of Mr Clarke’s parish having left him, for a preacher of harsher doctrines— Of Mr Boylston’s family, his Son John only attended with us— We dined as usual after the services of the day— I received by express from Governor Lincoln an invitation, as President of the Agricultural Society of the County of Worcester, to attend their Cattle Show, and dinner next Wednesday; which I declined, informing the Governor that I would call at his house, on my passage through Worcester to-morrow. Mr Clarke called after dinner. This is the fifth successive annual visit that I have paid to Mr Boylston at Princeton. The first was in 1821. with my father: and this in all probability will be the last— The visits have all been short; and all until the present one much alike— Until now Mr Boylston has always been in health while I was here, and full of pleasant Conversation— He is now confined to his chamber and easy Chair—having watchers in his bed-room every night; and though for the moment relieved from immediate danger, in constant terror of sudden death, and with little hope of surviving the Winter— His cordial hospitality remains unchanged, and this house will remain upon my memory, for the few days I have myself to continue on earth; as one of those which have contributed to the enjoyments of my life— Its retirement is one of its charms; there being no other visitable house in the Town; and the vicinity of Wachusett Hill, which though three miles distant, seems as if always ready to enter the door, and carries with it a forethought of eternity, solemnizes the Scene, till melancholy mellows into pleasure— To the mansion and to the Hill I am now to give the last parting salutation.
8. VI— Worcester— Brookfield— Ware.

We took leave of Mr Boylston and left Princeton, at 8 O’Clock this morning; immediately after breakfast— He had been seized in the night with the cramps in the stomach; with which since his last illness, he is frequently afflicted, and which keep him in constant alarm— When I parted from him, he said it was for the last Time, and when I said I hoped not; but that I should visit him again next year, he shook his head but made no reply— Lessing says that it was a part of the philosophy of the antient Romans to look at Death always under cheering aspects—“Nullaque ei tristis imago.” The true Christian looks forward to it with deep anxiety but with elevated hope— The man of the world considers it as a part of the destiny to which he is doomed, and for which it only behooves him to be always prepared— Animal nature alone shrinks from extinction, and dreads the approach of Death, as much on the verge of four score, as at twenty-five— I rode with grave thoughts to Worcester, where, after stopping with the Carriage at Thomas’s, I called on Governor Lincoln at his house, and spent an hour with him— Saw Mrs Lincoln, and Mr Waldo, J. Davis the member of Congress from the district, Dr Fiske, my old Classmate, Pliny Merrick, W. Lincoln the Governor’s brother; Mr Earle, editor of the newspaper; who mentioned the issue of the recent elections at Baltimore for the Legislature of Maryland, and in Delaware for a member of Congress, vicissitudes of fortune— The Governor had missed of seeing his brother the Governor of Maine, on his recent visit to Portland; and could therefore add little to what he had heretofore said to me concerning the Eastern boundary question with Great Britain; but he said he had conversed with several persons of distinguished character and influence in Maine, concerning it; and found them all reasonable, and well disposed— At half past twelve we proceeded upon our Journey; the Governor having walked with me to the Inn; where we parted— We rode through Leicester and Spencer to Brookfield; at which place we dined—and then continued through Western to Ware— We arrived just at the dusk of evening, and took lodgings for the Night at Phelps’s tavern: a house with comfortable and even elegant accommodations— In almost all the towns through which we passed, we saw new buildings for manufactories. Whatever there was of flourishing appearance any where was of this character. Ware itself is a new town; and like Lowell, almost a new Creation— The manufacturing Establishments here, are large, and apparently very flourishing— But they are owned in Boston; and the heavy depretiation of the Stock, in the Companies owning them casts ominous conjecture upon the future prospects of this smiling village.
9. V:30. Springfield— Hartford.

We took an early breakfast at Ware, and left it a quarter before seven; and after riding 24. Miles stopped at Phelps tavern in Springfield. Mr John Calhoun the Representative of this Town, in the Legislature of the State had written to my Son George, expressing an earnest wish that I would pass through Springfield, and make a short stop there on my passage— George had answered him that I should probably be there this morning; and he was expecting me. We arrived there just before eleven, and Mr Calhoun came in a few minutes after we had alighted. Numerous other Visitors afterwards came in, among whom were Coll. Lee Superintendant of the United States Armoury. My old Classmate at Harvard, Phelps, now Sheriff of the County of Hambden, Mr Lathrop, member of the last Congress Mr Shepherd of the manufactory: and several
of the inhabitants of the town. I visited with Coll. Lee the public armoury, and saw the workmen employed at all the successive operations of making muskets— Forging, turning, filing, stocking, browning, and proving the barrels are the principal processes; to which are added the making of the locks, pans, ramrods, bayonets, trickers and guards, Stocks, and the screws and pins by which the instrument is compounded— Mr Lee told me there were fifty two pieces to each musket, and one hundred and ninety seven operations in making it— There are 270 workmen, constantly employed at this armoury— The number of Mills which I visited, and where the works are carried on was eight or ten, besides the Arsenal where the arms are deposited, and the building where they are proved— A Salute was fired when I came to the Arsenal, from the Square before it. The Superintendent invited me to visit his quarters, but I declined for want of time— He told me that a whole day would barely suffice to view all the works minutely, and I thought that a whole week of repeated re-examination might be usefully devoted to the inspection— But I had not more than two hours in which I hurried through the whole, and during which the rain was falling in floods. The objects passed so rapidly before me that I had scarcely a moment for making enquiries which might have suggested themselves upon a more deliberate view— Coll. Lee told me that the Iron of which the muskets are made was from Connecticut. The Stocks of Black Walnut from New-Jersey and Pennsylvania— Each musket costs 10 dollars, and weighs 10 1/2 lb— I left these works with regret that I had not more time for surveying them, and returned to Phelps’s tavern, where my Classmate of that name, Coll. Lee, Mr Calhoun, and two or three others dined with us— The town of Springfield is one of the most flourishing in the Commonwealth; to which not only the national armoury, but the manufactures in it and in the vicinity essentially contribute. Its aspect has so changed that I should not have known I had ever been there before; which I had, several times— The last on the 27th. of January 1809— At half past two, we resumed our Journey, and rode without stopping more than five minutes, 26 miles to Hartford; the rain pouring down the whole time, as it had done from the moment of our leaving Ware, this morning. The country over which we travelled, especially from Springfield is fine, but the sear and yellow leaf of autumn is falling from the trees; the rain made our travelling very heavy, and the storm cast a gloom over the whole day— We reached Hartford about half past seven, of a dark and dismal night, and found excellent accommodations and a cheerful fire at Ripley’s U. S. Hotel. Mr Bailey of the Eastern Shore of Maryland, Mr Daggett, formerly a Senator of the United States, and now holding Court in this City, as judge of the Supreme Court of the State, Mr John Russ heretofore a member of Congress, Mr Parsons, and some other gentlemen called in the course of the Evening. To beguile the dreary hours of my three days ride from Boston to this place; two of which have been of almost continual rain I have read through the third number of the American Quarterly Review with exception of the last Article in it, written by myself. Some of the Articles are amusing, and some instructive— Those upon the Construction of Ships, upon the judicial right to pronounce Legislative Acts unconstitutional, and upon the Law of Marriage and Divorce, engaged much of my attention— That upon German Literature, and that upon Florida were not altogether satisfactory.— The weather has intercepted the views of Nature, which might otherwise have occupied a large portion of my time with observation, and the face of the Country has only led me to the conclusion that the establishment of manufactures alone preserves it from decay.
10. V:30. Candle-light— Steam-boat M’Donough— Long-Island Sound.

I lighted my candle, and wrote this morning two hours before breakfast— From that time a succession of numerous visitors called upon me; among whom was Mr Terry, the Mayor of the City, heretofore a member of the 15th. Congress, who told me that he came officially in execution of a Resolution of the City Councils, directing him to visit me in the event of my passing through here—also my old School mate Deane—whom I last saw three years ago at Philadelphia— Some of the professors and Students of the new college, and numbers of persons otherwise unknown to me— It rained heavily all the morning— The proprietors of the Steam-boat Oliver Ellsworth sent me a Letter, offering her to my disposal for to-morrow: which I declined, under the determination to proceed this day. The departure of the Boat was postponed an hour, but the rain continued unabated when we embarked at Noon, in the Steamboat M’Donough, Captain Beebe, after we were there Commodore Hull came on board, and informed me he was on his way to Boston. He took leave immediately, as we left the wharf, descending Connecticut river 50 miles to its mouth at Saybrook— The continued rain intercepted the pleasing view of the succession of landscapes on the banks of the river, but we stopped to land passengers at Middletown and Saybrook, and viewed as we past them, Weathersfield, and East and South Haddam, and other flourishing villages— If the foul weather had continued Captain Beebe’s intention was to have stopped for the night at Saybrook, rather than enter upon the Sound; but it cleared off about four in the afternoon, and the evening was fair— Mr Bailey of Maryland, with his wife and daughter Ann of 11 or 12 were among the passengers— Ann played upon the Piano in the Lady’s cabin, remarkably well for her years. Several young men, by the name of Williams, Parsons, two, and Edwards came with us, as companions to my Son John— One or two left us at Middletown, one or two at Saybrook, and three concluded to go on with us to New-York— We came into the Sound just at Dark— The Captain had a small bed made up for me in the forward Cabin, and partitioned off by two or three flags— I finished in the boat a Letter to my Son Charles that I had begun at Hartford, but had not patience to write more.
11. VI. New-York— New-Brunswick— Trenton.

After a quiet night I found on rising that the boat had entered the East river, and soon after, the light at Frog’s Neck was extinguished just as we were passing before it— At 7. A.M. just after Sun-rise we landed at New-York, and walked to the City Hotel, where we breakfasted— From that time till noon, a succession of visitors called—and I was urged to stop a day or two in the City. I was informed that a Committee would wait upon me with a formal invitation to that effect. But I received two Letters, one written here last Saturday morning by Mr Southard informing me that he was then immediately going on to Trenton, with the intention of proceeding on Tuesday, for Washington. The other from G. Sullivan, dated the 9th. and saying that after Mr Southard had written the above Letter, at the moment of his departure from New-York, and not having time to write again himself, he had desired him to inform me that he had received a Letter from Mr Clay, stating the necessity that all the members of the Administration should be at Washington by the 10th.— That day is already past—but I resolved to proceed at once, whatever the occasion of this sudden Summons may be— I mentioned this to Mr King, who had strongly urged me to stay, as my
motive for declining, and at his request consented that it should be publicly spoken of as my reason. I received also a Letter signed by William Patterson, William M. M’Donald, Solomon Etting, Luke Tiernan, David Hoffman, and Richard B. Magruder, as a Committee from an assemblage of Citizens at Baltimore, inviting me in the most friendly and earnest manner to stop there a few days on my return towards Washington— I concluded to reserve my answer to this Letter till I should reach Philadelphia, where I hoped to overtake Mr Southard— I received also a Letter dated the 5th. instt. from Mrs Adams at Washington. I had some conversation with judge Thompson upon political topics, and some with the Collector of the Port, upon the prospects of the Revenue, which continue at this Port to be favourable— At noon I embarked in the Steam-boat Emerald, Captain Jenkins— Mr King accompanied me to the boat, and there introduced to me a french man named Pugnet, a fellow passenger— Blunt goes with me to Philadelphia; and I met also a Mr Winslow of Charleston S.C. who visited me about a month since at Quincy— We reached New-Brunswick at 4. P.M. and took Stages to Trenton— Messrs. Blunt Pugnet and Winslow came by invitation with me— We arrived about nine in the Evening at Trenton, and lodge at the Steamboat Inn— Mr Pugnet was an officer in the French armies in the campaigns of 1812. 13. 14. and 15. and was wounded at the Battle of Waterloo— He spoke with much interest of the Events of those times; without passion, and without pretensions.
12. V:30. Philadelphia— United States Hotel— Mansion House.

At six this morning we embarked in the Steam-boat Burlington. Captn Mr Pugnet went ashore at Bordentown— At ten we landed at Philadelphia—a very great crowd of People were assembled on the wharf, who as I passed through them greeted me with three hearty cheers— Great numbers of them followed me to the United States Hotel, where upon my entering the house this cheering was repeated— Of my acquaintance Mr John Vaughan only had met me at the boat— I found at the Hotel several others, and Mr Sergeant immediately afterwards came in— They insisted with extreme earnestness on my remaining here this day, and told me that that house being fully they had engaged apartments for me at the Mansion House, now kept by Head, and newly fitted up— Finding that Mr Southard was in the City, I sent a request to him to call upon me, and in a few minutes he came— He informed me that the Letter from Mr Clay, on the receipt of which, he had left with George Sullivan the message for me, which induced me to come on without stopping at New-York, was written under the apprehension of an impending War with the Winebago Indians; and an impression that some decisive step should be taken which would require a deliberate consultation of the whole Cabinet— But by advices since received it appears that the two Indians who had committed the murders which it was expected would kindle the war have surrendered themselves up to the authorities of the United States; and that the danger of further immediate hostilities has subsided. The necessity for my immediate return to Washington being thus removed I consented to remain here this day, and came to the lodgings which had been engaged for me at the Mansion House. The Count de Survilliers, and the Prince de Musignano visited me before I left the United States Hotel; and I met Bishop White, going to call on me, as I was passing from one house to the other— From the time when I entered the mansion house, till 3 O’Clock, there was a constant stream of visitors
the greater part of whom were unknown to me— Among them was Mr Moore the director of the mint, who brought with him a small sealed box, received from Mr Gallatin, containing a brass pound Troy Weight, made after the standard Imperial Pound Troy, proclaimed by Act of Parliament. Mr Moore said he had received this some time since, and had kept it till now, to open it in my presence; and he wished me to sign a Certificate of this operation; to which I readily consented— Upon which he broke the Seals, opened the box, and drew out the Troy Pound, which had been made with great care— There was with it a certificate of Mr Gallatin, annexed to one of verification from Captain Kater, who at Mr Gallatin’s request had performed the comparison with the imperial Standard Pound— The Superscriptions on the box were in Mr Gallatin’s handwriting, and the Seals were with his Seal at arms—both well known to me— Mr Moore had drawn up the form of a certificate to be signed and sealed by me, to which I suggested a slight addition, by inserting the inscription engraved upon the Pound— Mr Moore will bring it to be executed to morrow— I dined with Mr Southard, and my Son John at Mr Sergeant’s: and early in the Evening called on Mr Hopkinson— Found him and his family in deep affliction; having within this week received intelligence of the death of his Son Lieutenant Alexander H. Hopkinson, upon Service in the Mediterranean Squadron— He spoke to me of the desire of the Count de Survilliers, that his Son and daughter might have a passage in our Ship of the Line, Delaware, which is soon going out to the Mediterranean. I returned to the Mansion House, and received visitors again till after ten— Degrand remained with me till Midnight—talking of politics and complaining of the deputy collector— I told him he must address his complaints in form and in writing to the Secretary of the Treasury.
13. VI. Newcastle— Frenchtown. Steam boat United States— Trippe— Chesapeake Bay.

Mr Bache, the Postmaster, yesterday delivered to me, a Letter, which I found was a duplicate of the invitation from Baltimore, which I had received at New-York— Thinking I had made no adequate excuse for declining this manifestation of kind feeling, from my friends in that place I wrote this morning an answer, accepting it, and promising to pass the day there on Monday—which I sent to the Post Office— Mr Southard breakfasted with us and immediately afterwards, I went with him and visited the Navy-Yard, where we were received by Commodore Bainbridge, and by Major Miller with his Guard of Marines— A Salute was fired on our arrival. We went on board of the Line of Battle Ship Pennsylvania now on the Stocks building to carry 136 guns, and said to be the largest ship that will float upon the Ocean— She is built chiefly of Live Oak, and looks like a City in herself. She is under a permanent covered building, as are a frigate and a Sloop of War, building at her side— Commodore Bainbridge introduced to me the other Officers in service at the yard, and shewed me all the Offices connected with it— From the Navy-Yard we went to the Asylum for Seamen, a Marine Hospital building under the superintendance of Mr Strickland. It is 384 feet front, and 80 feet deep, and will be when finished a magnificent edifice— Mr Strickland shewed us the plan of the building, and went with us over the parts of it that are finished. They have here, some granite, resembling, though much inferior to that of Quincy. They build here also much of marble; of which they have fine quarries, not far distant— We returned to the Mansion house shortly before eleven and I received visitors again till near twelve. Mr Moore the director of the Mint came, and I signed and Sealed the certificate of opening the box containing the Troy pound weight from England— Mr Biddle, the President of the Bank, brought me the books of dividends on the U.S. Bank Stock, on which I signed receipts for the two last. Mr Jones the Collector gave me a statement
of the accrueing Revenue of the present year at this Port— Mr Lowndes introduced to me several persons from South-Carolina— Among the visitors was Captain Wills, who was master of the ship America, in which we came from Hamburg to Philadelphia, in the year 1801— The old man had an appearance of decay, and of poverty, and asked me if I could not give him a place— Judge Washington is holding the U.S. Circuit Court here— Among the visitors I should have named Josiah Randall. Before I went to the Boat J. Sergeant took leave being obliged to attend the Eulogy to be delivered upon the late Chief of Justice Tilghman by H. Binney at Noon— At the same hour I came on board the Steam-boat Delaware, Captain Wheldon— Mr Jones and several other of my friends accompanied me to the boat on the wharf, a crowd of several thousands of people were assembled; many of whom followed me into the boat, and thronged the deck till it became almost impassable— I then addressed those of them nearest to me, and told them I should be glad to shake hands with them all, if they could make a passage for one another to come to me; which they immediately did, and between two and three hundred of them shook hands with me, and passed off till the signal bell, which had been a full half our delayed, rang for the departure of the boat. All but the Passengers then left her except Degrand who lost the moment for stepping on to the wharf and came with us to Newcastle— Saying he would pay a visit to his friend Dupont at Wilmington. As the boat left the wharf three hearty cheers were given by the assembled multitude, which were repeated when she passed down before the wharves after fetching a sweep round the upward stream— I returned their salutation by a bow; waving the hand, and saying, “God bless you all.” There was not the slightest disorder— These shadows of good will from my fellow-citizens I hope affect me suitably—grateful to them and to heaven, for their benevolence; imploring aid for the fulfilment of the duties, which they reward and impose, and mindful of the pinnacle from which they warn me to prepare for descending I trust that no vain or unworthy sentiment of exultation mingles with the cheering glow of the thoughts, and the solemn reflections which they excite in my mind— The excitement and confidence of my friends at Philadelphia, is at this moment in the flood, from their success last Tuesday, in carrying the election of John Sergeant, as their Representative in Congress, against Joseph Hemphill. Mr Southard goes with me to Baltimore; and proceeds thence immediately to Washington. Among our passengers to Newcastle were Andrew Armstrong heretofore Consul at Hayti—a Mr. Campbell of North-Carolina; and Dr Anderson, of Chester, a member elect of the present Congress— At half past four, we landed at Newcastle; Mr Southard travelled with me in the Stage to Frenchtown, and at half past seven we embarked in the Steamboat United States Captain Trippe for Baltimore.
14. II.30— VII.15. Baltimore.

Captain Trippe informed me last Evening that he had been requested by the Committee to give them immediate notice of my arrival at Baltimore; that they might come and receive me on board the boat at the wharf— But as this would be giving them useless trouble I resolved to go to the Inn immediately upon the arrival of the boat, and desired Captain Trippe to give notice to the Committee, in the morning that I was there. I turned into a birth early in the Evening, and at half past two was awaked by my Son John with the notice that we were at the wharf. We came immediately to Barnum’s Hotel, where I went again to bed and slept till Sunrise— It was still later when I rose, and a few minutes after, Mr David Hoffman
a member of the Committee came in— I told him that I had answered their invitation at Philadelphia, yesterday, and presumed Mr Patterson would receive my answer by the mail this morning, and that I had agreed to pass the day here to morrow. He said that an unexpected and embarrassing incident had occurred, in the death of Colonel Howard on Friday Night; as his funeral was fixed for tomorrow, and would necessarily occupy a great part of the day—and he asked if I could without inconvenience remain one day longer— I said that under such circumstances, and with a view to show my respect for the memory of Coll. Howard, I should readily attend the funeral, and would also remain here on Tuesday. Mr Hoffman then went to the meeting of the Committee, and they all called upon me after breakfast— They proposed to give notice that I would receive the Citizens of Baltimore, that I would receive their visits to-morrow and on Tuesday publishing to-morrow morning, their Letter of invitation and my answer to which I assented. I attended public worship, in the morning with Mr Patterson at the first Presbyterian Church, and heard Mr Nevins, from Luke 13–30. “And behold, there are last which shall be first, and there are first which shall be last”— After the service I spoke to Mr Nevins, and Mr Patterson introduced me to his Son, and to his grandson Jerome Buonaparte— Mr David Hoffman dined with us at Barnum’s and in the afternoon I attended with Mr Tiernan and Mr Hillen, at the Roman Catholic Cathedral— The service consisted of singing Selections from the Psalms with accompaniment of the organ; and a short Sermon upon the lesson of the morning, the parable of the Royal banquet— After the Service, Mr Tiernan shewed me the two large pictures presented to this Church by the late and the present kings of France— All the members of the Committee took tea and spent the Evening with me, and introduced several of their friends. It rained heavily with little interruption the whole day; notwithstanding which Mr Southard went on to Washington— I received a note from the family of Coll. John Eager Howard, informing me of his decease and that his funeral would be from his late residence at ten O’Clock to-morrow morning— Mr Benjamin Chew, his brother in Law, came also to give me the same notice, which he said they wished to do in the most respectful manner. He spoke also of his own antient regard and friendship for my father, with some allusion to the political hostility to me of Coll. Howard’s eldest Son, which he intimated was on the present occasion altogether discarded— I told him that I could entertain no other feelings than of respect for Coll. Howard and his family—and that I should take a melancholy satisfaction in attending the funeral, as affording me the opportunity to shew that respect:—and with oblivion of all political hostilities whatever. I wrote to Mrs Adams.

The invitation of the Committee with my answer were published in the newspapers this morning: with notice to the Citizens, that I should attend the funeral of Coll Howard, and would receive visitors from 3 to 4 this afternoon, and from 7 to 10 this Evening— Before the funeral I received the visits of the members of the Cincinnati, with General Samuel Smith at their head, and his Son John Spear one of their number— Mr Patterson went with me in my Carriage to Belvidere the late residence of Coll. Howard, and thence in procession to the place of interment. The procession was very long, and attended by the militia of the City in military array, as well as by great multitudes of the Citizens. It made a circuit through the principal Streets of the City, and the day being fair the whole population of the City appeared to be in the procession or witnessing it from the sides of the Streets and the windows of the Houses— The funeral service, according to the forms of the episcopal church, but abridged, was performed partly by bishop Kemp, and partly by another Clergyman— The procession was not renewed in returning from the grave-yard— I had seen Coll. Howard when living only two or three times—the last on the day of General La Fayette’s entry at Baltimore, three years since. I this day took a last view of his lifeless face before the procession moved from his house— It was near three in the afternoon when I returned to Barnum’s tavern, and from 3 to 4. I received in the large Hall of the house a great number of Visitors— Then dined with the Committee and a small party of friends invited by them—about thirty— On retiring from them after dinner, I gave them for a toast, “the
the living, and the dead— Charles Carroll of Carrollton, and John Eager Howard.” and returning to the great Hall received visitors from 7 till 10 O’Clock in the Evening— They came in a continual unceasing stream to the number it could be scarcely less than of two thousand. The Hall was much crowded nearly the whole time, though few if any remained there more than ten minutes— I shook hands with them all; and among them all there were not twenty whom I had ever seen before— There were people of all classes, and all political opinions— There was last week an election for members of the State Legislature, in which the friends of the administration both in the City and County of Baltimore were unsuccessful; and it was followed by a duel, between two of the Candidates— The excitement remaining here was not less than I found it at Philadelphia; but it was not equally cheering— Among those who came there were no small number of my political adversaries, but with the exception of three or four, all of whom were intoxicated, they gave no manifestation of it— One man was noisy and boisterous and noisy for two or three minutes; and upon being asked his name answered that it was M’Mahon; a brother of the Candidate— One said to me that although opposed to me, he was glad to see me well—and to take me by the hand— I answered him “we are all friends here;[”]—and thanked him for his good will— One very much in liquor said while shaking my hand said—Mr President, I hope the Constitution will never be broken— I answered “I concur with you heartily in that wish; and hope also that your Constitution may never be broken.” By far the greater number barely came up, shook my hand, and passed off—some said a few words expressive of their cordiality, and many told me they hoped I should be re-elected— About ten O’Clock the Hall was nearly cleared, and I retired somewhat exhausted to bed.
16. VI.— North-Point. Battle ground.

I rose this morning refreshed by sleep, but later than usual, and anxious for the issue of the day. Immediately after breakfast I went, accompanied by the Committee, and by a few others to the Battle-ground near North-Point— Mr Patterson, and Mr James H. M’Culloch the Collector of the Port went with me in my Carriage— General M’Donald, Mr W. W. Barney, the Naval Officer, N. F. Williams, and several others followed in carriages, and on horseback— The distance is about nine miles from the town, over a barren country, covered great part of the way with forest trees, now undressing for the Winter. General M’Donald, Mr McCulloch, Barney and Williams had been in the Battle— M’Culloch and Williams, both wounded, and M’Culloch taken prisoner.— He had gone out as a volunteer though already then past the usual fighting age, and I was much entertained with his account of the incidents which occurred to him upon this expedition— He was wounded very near to the spot where General Ross was killed. There is a small monument erected by the company of first Mechanical Volunteers, attached to the 5th. Regiment of Maryland Militia, to the memory of Aquilla Randall, one of their number, who fell in the same action of the 12th. of September 1814— It is a pyramid of white stone, about four feet high resting on a pedestal with suitable inscriptions on its four sides— These inscriptions, with an account of the erection of the monument on the 28th. of July 1817. and the address of Captain B. C. Howard, commander of the company at the time are contained in Niles’s Register of the 2d of August of that year. Vol. 12— p. 367. There are no other traces of the action there at present though Mr Barney shewed me an Oak tree, in which he said more than twenty of the enemy’s musket bullets had lodged— We returned to the City about one O’Clock, riding round by the way of Fell’s point— I picked up under the wounded tree half a dozen white oak Acorns to plant them at Washington. After returning to the City, I received visitors again in great numbers till 4 O’Clock— Among them
were bishop Kemp, and many of the Clergy; all the foreign Consuls; the Mayor and the City Councils, and the President, Vice-President, Teachers and Students of St. Mary’s College— The Vice-President Mr Eccleston read to me a very handsomely written, and highly oratorical address; which I answered extemporaneously with great brevity; first to himself, and then by a short exhortation to the students— Among the visitors were also Dr. Glendy, his Colleague Mr Breckenridge, Mr Nevins, and Mr Burnap, whom I heard last Summer at Medford, and who is now preaching at the unitarian Church here— There were also Mr Wilson of Charleston S.C. whom I had seen at Quincy; Mr Gales, one of the Editors of the National Intelligencer, and Mr Salazar the Minister from the Republic of Colombia, who introduced to me, Mr Velez as Chargé d’Affaires from that Government, he being himself recalled, and shortly to return home— These were all yesterday or this morning from Washington, and Mr Salazar told me that Mrs Adams had been unwell— He spoke also of a complaint which by order of the Vice President Santander he had addressed to Mr Clay, against Beaufort S. Watts, our Charge d’Affaires at Bogota, for a very strange Letter which he wrote to the President Bolivar, and which he published— I told Mr Salazar that that Letter had been unauthorised, and was disapproved by me— He said Mr Clay had given him the same information— And he wished as much as possible to soften the complaint against Mr Watts, whose Letter he said had been attributed to indiscretion rather than to any evil intention— He said that on the 4th. of July last Mr Watts had given a public dinner, at which the Vice President Santander had attended, and he hoped the misunderstandings between them had been then in a great measure healed— I dined again with the Committee, and a party of about 30 persons, consisting of the members of the Cincinnati, and of the persons wounded at the battle of North Point— General S. Smith sat at my right hand, and the Collector M’Culloch, at my left— The dinner was short— A single toast was given by the Committee— “The United States of America— May other Countries learn from them, that the easy access of the People to their Rulers, is the means of confidence on the one side, and of right Government on the other.” Soon after which I gave “Ebony and Topaz”— Genl. Ross’s posthumous Coat of Arms, and the Republican Militiaman, who gave it.”—adding a short explanation of the allusion in the sentiment to the Tale of Voltaire— Upon retiring from the Table I offered my final thanks to the Committee and to the Citizens of Baltimore for the kindness of the reception they had given me and proposed as a toast “Baltimore—the monumental City— May the days of her safety be as prosperous and happy, as the days of her danger have been trying and triumphant.” I then received visitors again from 6 to 8 O’Clock—and after once retiring was obliged to go down again, and receive a fresh stream. On finally withdrawing, I addressed those remaining in the room, and requested each and every one of them, who had at home a wife, or a mother, or a sister, or a daughter, to shake hands for me with her, and tell her that in shaking hands with him I did in heart the same with her— I then went to Mr E. J. Coale’s, where there was a musical party and heard two Glees— The Zuyderzee, and the Derby Ram— Thence we went to Mr David Hoffman’s, where a party of Ladies were assembled, and where we had also music. Mr Cornelius performed on the Guitar, and Violin: and Miss Donaldson and Mr Charles Pinkney sung Italian Songs— Among the Ladies, besides Mrs Hoffman there were Mrs. J. S. Skinner, Mrs C. D. Williams, Miss Spear, Miss Stuart, Miss Meredith, Miss Pinkney, and some others. With Mrs Williams I had some conversation, and was much pleased. Between ten and eleven I returned to my lodgings, and sought the repose of night, grateful for the kind and friendly entertainment that I have experienced here—grateful to a higher power, for the expiration of the term that I have consented to remain here, and for the fulfilment of the promise which I had made in passing through this place two years since, when I missed receiving the invitation then intended for me.
17. VI. Washington.

I left Baltimore between nine and ten this Morning, in my own Carriage, which Mrs. Adams had sent there for us last Thursday, with the Coachman Mr Pomphrey— My Son John and Antoine were with me— The Committee in a Carriage, and about twenty Gentlemen on horseback came out with us as far as the Turnpike; where I got out of the Carriage, and they dismounted; and after I had returned them again my thanks for their kindness we finally parted. We stopped a few minutes at Merrill’s— Mr Proud was there—and five or six Gentlemen of the neighbourhood, whom he introduced to me— At four in the afternoon we arrived safe, and well at Washington, where I found my family well, excepting Mrs Adams, who though not confined is unwell, and a few days since was very ill— She had invited Messrs.Clay, Rush, Barbour and Southard to dine with us, which they did— I spent the Evening with my family My excursion of eleven weeks has been partially beneficial to my health— Care and Trouble belong to every age and every place— I have found them there: I meet them on returning here. But they end with life, and it is time for me to prepare earnestly for the end of life. I find creeping upon me an aversion to labour, the reverse of that devotion to it which has hitherto sustained me in all my trials— This is the most alarming symptom of my present moral condition— The remedy is in the hands of him who controuls the Will, as well as the actions of men— “So teach me to number my days that I may apply my heart unto Wisdom.”
18 IV:45.— Candle-light.

I found on my table yesterday, a great budget of Letters, the seals of which I left unbroken— This morning, from the moment of my rising till breakfast, I was employed in opening, and reading them without getting through the task— Setting aside applications and recommendations for office there was nothing in them worth the time consumed in the perusal of them—a reflection, which I find myself very often under the necessity of making— Of the immense multitudes of Letters that I have received and been doomed to read, since I have held my present Office; one small file would embrace all that are worth preserving— The visitors of this day noted in the margin, amounted I suppose to about 150. including the mail contractors— The first of them, the Revd. Mr Dugan came to solicit a contribution for a Roman Catholic Church at Brownsville— Mr Black for a subscription for a Chart of the Coast of the United States to be published by Mr Blunt— Next came two men claiming a reward for taking Willis Anderson, a man charged with murder, and for the apprehension of whom, a proclamation issued on the 10th. of September, offering a reward— He was taken in Pennsylvania, brought to the District, and lodged in jail yesterday. I referred the men to the Department of State where they received the reward— Mr Graham came with two persons from the State of Ohio, Drake and Chafey, still remonstrating against the fixing of the Land Office at Tiffin— The time at which it had been determined that this should be done was the first of November next; but upon their representation, that the unhealthiness of the place has been confirmed even by the experience of the last Summer, and of the present time, I agreed that the final decision should again be postponed till the meeting of Congress— This subject
is contested, as if the fate of the Union depended upon it— Mr Clay came and introduced the Committee of the Mail Contractors who had passed a written resolution, that they would in a body visit the President, and the Secretary of State— And they enquired at what time I could with convenience receive them. As some of them were going away to-morrow morning I fixed upon four O’Clock this afternoon— They then came in procession; upwards of a hundred in number— I received them in the Winter Parlour; shook hands with them all; and at the suggestion of Mr Clay, who said they would perhaps be glad to see the house, shewed them, the rooms on the lower floor, and those above with the exception of the bed-chambers— There was cake and wine served to them, and I drank success to them all through Highways and By ways. Their visit was over in about half an hour— These are persons from all parts of the Union who at this time of the year come to offer proposals of contracts for carrying the Mail— Each contract is for three or four years, but a certain proportion of them expire every year, and this is the time for the renewal of them— As the Post roads, and the number of the mail conveyances increase this body of men increases every year with them— This I believe is the first time, that they have assembled and acted as a body. Besides them, the visitors of this day were principally the Officers of the Government— Mr Darby the Geographer brought a Gazetteer that he has recently published. Commodore Rodgers I saw for the first time since his return from the Mediterranean— Mr Duval, is the Governor of the Territory of Florida— Coll. Roberdeau called with two Officers who have been employed on surveys in Vermont, and he afterwards sent me an old rusty remnant of a Coat of Mail, found there, underground— Coll. Huger called with his Son, a Lieutenant in the army; for whom he wishes to obtain a furlough to visit France— In the Evening I went to Judge Cranch’s, and delivered to him a Letter from his Sister Greenleaf— Found there Mr James Greenleaf, Mr and Mrs Dawes, Elliot’s, Goddards and the judges own family, a company of near twenty persons— There was music. Returning home I found W. S. Smith here— My Frye had called in the morning. My Son John this Evening asked my consent to his marriage with Mary C. Hellen— I promised to give him an answer, in the course of a few days.

I was called from breakfast to see Mr Anderson the Comptroller; and from that time a succession of visitors followed till past 3. O’Clock P.M. chiefly of persons in office under the government— Mr Clay spoke to me of Instructions to be given to Mr Gallatin, respecting the question of the North Eastern boundary— to Mr Poinsett, respecting the denunciation of him by the Legislative Assembly of the State of Vera-Cruz; and to Mr W. Tudor, who is appointed Charge d’Affaires at Rio de Janeiro. Also of the complaint against Beaufort S. Watts, by the Vice-President of the Republic of Colombia— I had a long Conversation with Mr Anderson, upon the political topics of a general nature— Mr Rowe is one of the Mail Contractors from the State of Ohio, who not having been here with the rest of the body yesterday, came this morning alone— I shewed him over the house, as I had done with the others. Mr Paimboeuf is from Louisiana, and came with Mr Brent to solicit the appointment of Consul at Curaçao. He has been an applicant before; and is recommended by some of the Delegation from his State— I directed that a Commission should be made out for him. Mr Fenner has been for some years a Clerk in the War Department— But in the sedentary life—
and occupations of his office his health became disordered, and his medical adviser informed him that his continuance there would be at the peril of his life— He obtained some time since a leave of absence from his Office; providing a substitute for the performance of its duties, and has been qualifying himself as a Minister of the Episcopal Church. He now wishes to exchange Offices with Mr Walter Addison, who is Chaplain at the Navy Yard; and who is equally desirous of the Exchange— His office is in his person merely nominal, and a Sinecure; and the Salary at the War Department is more than double the other— I told Mr Fenner that with the assent of the Heads of the War and Navy Departments, I was not aware of any objection to the proposed exchange—but he enquired whether as Chaplain he would be liable to an order to go to Sea— He was apprehensive that his health would not admit of this— I said I could not promise him any exemption; but that on this subject he would receive all suitable information from the Secretary of the Navy— I walked before dinner to the foot of College Hill— Signed an order for the appointment of Sineus Conklin, as Light-house keeper on Plum-Island, State of New-York, with a Salary of 350 dollars a year; and wrote to my Son George—
20. V:30. Race-ground walk.

I feel already inconvenience from the intermission of my usual morning’s exercise, though it has not of late been efficacious to the preservation of my health— This morning I walked to the race-ground, and there gathered about a quart of white oak acorns, which had fallen from the trees, and many of which had already germinated as they laid on the surface of the Earth— After Breakfast, I planted in the Southern Seedling bed in the Garden 50 white Oak Acorns in one Row— 50 Chesnuts in one Row and in the Eastern bed 50 black muscle Plums in one Row and 6. Battle ground white Oak Acorns in the centre of a Row, about the middle of the bed— Of my former plantations I find in the Southern bed, planted last November and December 21 Walnut trees up and living the stems from one to four inches long; the leaves of those that first came up, in June, fallen or falling— They have been coming up the whole Summer; as at Quincy. There are also about 15 wild cherry trees, and ten Althaeas self planted— Some of the cherry trees are about nine inches high, and the Althaeas are three or four feet, though the first came up in July. The leaves of most of the Cherry trees, and of all the Althaea’s are still in full verdure. In the Eastern Seedling bed, There are 20 Walnut trees, the nuts of which were planted the 20th of April last. They have also been coming up all Summer, and are as much grown as those which were planted in the Southern bed the November and December before. None of the Stones or seeds which I planted in the Eastern bed last May June and July have come up— In my Seedling Pots the two Apple trees, the pippins of which were planted the 27th. of May are living, three Oranges and one Tamarind— In the two Tumblers, a dozen Oranges, but no others— They exhibit their Roots running down the sides of the tumblers, through the glass in a very curious manner. Young Mr Elliot who was graduated last Winter at the Columbian College came to solicit an appointment as a Clerk, in any of the Departments; but I knew of no vacancy. Governor Barbour came to say he was obliged to go off immediately to Virginia, where his youngest Son lies very dangerously ill of an inflammatory fever— He takes Dr Lovell, the Surgeon General with him, but was so deeply alarmed by the Accounts from Mrs Barbour, that he had little hope of finding
the child alive. Mr Clay spoke of the appointments to be made of District Attornies in New-Hampshire, and in East Tennessee— I desired him to send me a Commission to W. Plumer jr. for New-Hampshire; though I know not whether he will accept the appointment— Mr Bulfinch came with Major Queen and Mr Marden, who is putting up two furnace Stoves under the Rotunda, in the Capitol— From their description of them, I thought that one might be advantageously put up, in the lower Story of the President’s House; and went down with them to examine the floor for that purpose— It was found that the furnace could easily be placed there, and I promised to go up, and see those at the Capitol, monday Morning about Sunrise— Coll. Roberdeau called and brought me the box Chronometer, which I have usually kept in my Cabinet— Mr Rush brought me his minutes of business kept during my absence, with a number of accompanying papers— Coll. Thomas dined with us— He is going to-morrow for New-York— I signed an order to appoint Edward Newton, Keeper of the Beacon light, federal point, North-Carolina, with a Salary of 400 dollars a year. Also 16. Land grants— Mary Hellen went to Mr Frye’s.
21. VI:30.— Up in the Night— Mrs Adams ill.

About half past one O’Clock this morning, Mrs Adams was seized with illness: sudden and violent in the extreme. When she first found herself ill she left the bed and went into the adjoining chamber to the bed where Mary Hellen usually sleeps— I was soon after awakened by her groans; and leaping out of bed, followed the sound, till I found her in the bed in the other chamber, in great suffering, and unable to speak. I immediately roused the servants in the house, and sent for Dr Huntt who shortly afterwards came, and administered an emetic, and applied mustard blisters to her feet arms and breast— In about two hours the emetic operated, and she obtained some relief. The Doctor then retired, and I left two of the woman Servants with her and returned to bed— This day she has been extremely feeble and exhausted, but without much fever. Her Sister Smith came and will pass the night here. Dr Huntt called several times in the course of the day. I heard this morning Mr Hawley at St. John’s Church, from Matthew 11.15. “He that hath ears to hear, let him hear”— And he read prayers for the 19th. Sunday after Trinity— In the afternoon I heard a Stranger at Mr Baker’s, from James 2.19. “The devils also, believe and tremble.” And in the Evening I walked with Abigail Adams, to the Unitarian Church, and heard Mellish Motte, from Deuteronomy 6.5. “Thou shalt love the Lord thy God”— This young man was the Classmate and Chambermate of my Son George at Harvard— His Sermon was very well written, and in discoursing upon the Love of God, he naturally connected with it topics of goodwill to men, benevolence and Charity, congenial to the true Spirit of Christianity— His delivery is not so good as his composition—and in hearing him I could not defend myself from the reflection how severe a loss this church, and the whole community have sustained in the decease of Mr Robert Little. He was perhaps over zealous in the peculiar doctrines of his sect, to many of which I do not assent, and he introduced them into his pulpit oftener, and more in the Spirit of controversy than was agreeable to me— But with this exception he was the most instructive and I will add the most entertaining preacher upon whose public ministration I ever permanently attended— His discourses were replete with ecclesiastical learning and biblical criticism— His moral doctrines devoted to the best feelings of the heart; and he could occasionally add to the kind and affectionate precepts of brotherly love, the sting of wit and the scourge of Satire to promote the cause of Virtue— I knew not how much I should feel the vacuum made by his loss until he was gone. He died at Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, on the 6th. of August last. I have this day begun the attempt to retrieve the arrears of this Journal which in my late journeying have run up to the amount of 16 days. I have however constantly kept the minutes of a diary— Steam-boat and Stage travelling will not admit of more. I have great difficulty in effecting so much.
22. VI:30. Walk to Capitol— Queen— Marden— Furnaces.

Mrs Adams is better; though still confined to her bed. I yesterday told my Son John, that I should not persist in objecting to his marriage with Mary C. Hellen but that it should be deferred until he should find some mode of employment which would afford him the means of supporting a family. Mary Hellen returned here from Mr Frye’s— I went up this morning to the Capitol, and viewed the furnaces under the Rotunda with Major Queen and Mr Marden— And I determined upon making the experiment of having one erected in the President’s House— Soon after I came home it began to rain, and continued raining with a heavy gale, with little intermission through the day and evening— Mr Southard was my only visitor— I shewed him a Letter that I had received from Mr Hopkinson of Philadelphia; repeating a request about which he had spoken to me, in behalf of the Count de Survilliers, that his Son and daughter might have a passage, on board the line of Battle ship Delaware, going to the Mediterranean. Mr Southard said he had received a direct application to the same effect— That they might have the passage; unless there were political considerations for declining to comply with the Count’s request. I thought there were none of sufficient importance to justify the refusal— Mr Southard said it would be necessary for him to ascertain where they would wish to be landed, and that some arrangement should be made to provide for the expenses on their passage without occasioning a charge on the public funds— We spoke also of the appointment of Commissioners of the Navy board— Commodore Rodgers, since his return from the command of the Squadron in the Mediterranean has been recommissioned to the board. But Tingey is extremely desirous of withdrawing from the board, and of going back to his command at the Navy yard here— Particularly as there is an unsettled question of Rank, between him and Rodgers, which may slumber unless they are brought together as members of the same Commission— We looked over the list of Captains in the Navy, for me to substitute in the place of Tingey, and found none among those of early date, who could without inconvenience be selected— The practice has been to confine the appointments at the board, to the officers of the longest standing—and who have commanded Squadrons: I suggested to Mr Southard the Consideration, whether it might not be proper in future to appoint one of the three, from among the junior Captains, in which event we should now have no difficulty in making a choice— I signed an order for the discharge from prison of Isaac Russell. Mrs W. S. Smith remains yet with us.
23. V. Lamplight.

Flaugeac is a young man from Louisiana, Son of Garrigues Flaugeac, and is now residing here as a student at Law, and learning the language. He brought me a Letter of Introduction from Mr W. L. Brent, the member of the House of Representatives from that State— Coll. Perrault came with Coll. Roberdeau—he is an officer of the Corps of Topographical engineers, and has recently returned from the Surveys for a Canal over the Isthmus of Florida— He is a native of France— Karthaus is a visitor from Baltimore, much concerned in projects for Canals— Mr Clay spoke to me again of the Instructions to be prepared for Mr Gallatin relating to the North-eastern frontier— He spoke also, under some excitement, of the political course of conduct pursued by Mr M’lean the Postmaster General: whom he believes to be bitterly though insidiously hostile to the Administration— Mr M’lean has
greatly improved the condition of the Post-Office Department since he has been at its head; and is perhaps the most efficient officer that has ever been in that place— But it is a place of more patronage, and personal influence, than those of all the other Heads of Departments put together— In the exercise of this influence, Mr M’lean has so managed as to conciliate to himself all the opposition party, while every other member of the administration has been the object of the most violent and outrageous abuse— Many of the friends of the administration believe that Mr M’lean has secured to himself this exemption from persecution, by a system of duplicity in his conduct; and by favouring so far as has been in his power, the views of the opposition— I have been slow to believe this; and while he himself has repeatedly protested his firm and faithful attachment to the administration, no decisive act of his has been detected, necessarily importing his insincerity. Mr Clay mentioned some cases in the present distribution, and modification of his Contracts, which have an unfavourable aspect; but nothing of which it appears to me that notice can be taken— His friendship is suspicious— His war is in disguise— General Taylor is upon his return from a Northern Tour to Norfolk; and General Brown returned this morning from a visit to the Artillery School of practice at Old Point Comfort—or Fortress Monroe— The General spoke of his great Tour of Inspection, upon which he was gone all the last Summer; of the recent alarms of War, with the Winebago Indians; and of the political movements, and prospects of his old friend DeWitt Clinton which he disapproves and laments— Mr Brice came as a solicitor of contributions for a Presbyterian foreign Missions; but without any satisfactory explanation of the objects of their call. In my walk before dinner I stopped at Mr Frye’s, and saw Mrs Frye, who has been quite ill: and is yet too much indisposed to go abroad— Signed 50 Blank Navy Warrants.

Mr Graham brought a claim of compensation to himself, for some agency in a Settlement of certain Indian Affairs, upon the allowance of which he wishes me to decide— He left a paper with me to explain the claim more fully than he did verbally and referred me to the Act of Congress upon which it was founded— He intimated that he had in the first instance waived the claim, when Mr Crawford was in the Treasury Department, upon the ground that he was receiving then an extra Salary for other service— But from the time when that extra Salary ceased he thought himself entitled to this per Centage, of two and a half per cent, upon a Sum of about 85000 dollars for which he has accounted— I took the paper for consideration and for consultation with the Secretary of the Treasury— Governor Duval of Florida said he had been informed that reports had been made to me that he was hostile to the Administration, and had spoken in the most abusive language of me— I said he had been misinformed— I had heard nothing like that: and if I had, knowing his character, I should not have believed it— But that somebody last Winter, I did not recollect who, had said or written to me that he was not friendly to the Administration— He said he had always spoken in the most respectful terms of me— That he was indeed very much attached to the General Jackson, and disliked Mr Clay—not for any thing that had lately happened, but for affairs of long standing. That he had never believed there had been any thing dishonourable in my conduct; nor ever given countenance to any such report— I assured him I had never indulged a suspicion that he had. Mr Brent of Louisiana, and Governor Duval concurred in recommending a Mr Mason of Virginia, for the appointment of Navy Agent at Pensacola— I told them I believed that recommendation came too late— Mr Baker came to solicit a contribution for the poor of his Congregation— Dr Hannah brought a Letter of introduction and a small
packet for Mrs Adams, from Mrs Agnes Porter of London— Dr Hannah is an Englishman or a West Indian, who received his education in this Country, and has now come out with his family to settle as a Physician at New-York— Lieutt. Courtney is one of the surveying Engineers and called with General Macomb. Mr English has returned from the Mediterranean with Commodore Rodgers, and came to solicit further employment. I told him I was not aware of any service upon which he could be employed for the present— After some conversation with Mr Pleasonton, for whom I had sent for that purpose, I signed and gave him the order for the appointment of Richard Evans, as keeper of the Light House at Smith’s Point in Maryland, with a Salary of 350 dollars a year— I signed also 63 Blank single patents— This was the first day of the Washington Races— Johnson Hellen and John attended them.
25. V—15. Georgetown Walk.

I walked this morning before Breakfast to Georgetown, and returning stopped at Mr Rush’s house— He has been several days confined there, unwell, of which I was informed only by the National Intelligencer of yesterday Morning. The Servant who came to the door told me that he was not up; but so much recovered that he intended to go this day to the Treasury— He afterwards came to see me, but without transacting business— Mrs Johnson is a young woman of pleasing personal appearance, and education, who came to solicit an appointment of Clerk in any of the Departments for her husband— She gave me a full account of their domestic establishment, and their urgent wants; a mother, two Sisters—an infirm brother to support—all without means— She repeatedly expressed the hope and belief that I was accessible; and assured me of the everlasting gratitude, of the whole family, if I would give an Office to her husband— It is among the heaviest burdens of my place to hear this cry of distress almost every day of the year—often several times in a day, and scarcely ever to have it in my power to administer the desired relief— There is no pleader of this cause so eloquent as a young and handsome woman; and none who ought to be more firmly resisted— I told Mrs Johnson that the Law gave the appointment of Clerk’s in each Department, to the Head of the Department itself, and that any interposition on my part unless desired by them, was unusual and perhaps improper. I advised that her husband should apply personally to the heads of Departments, and furnish testimonials of good character, and fitness for the Office he wished to obtain, and if the Head of Department should consult me upon the appointment, I would say in favour of her husband what I could with propriety— Mr M’lean the Postmaster General said it was the first day since my return that he had been able to call upon me— That for the last fortnight he had been every day at his Office from early in the morning till Night— Having even his dinner sent him there from his house.
