He has now nearly got through his business with the contractors and says the new contracts will afford very great additional facilities, both to the transportation of the mail and for travellers— I desired him to furnish me at his convenience the usual annual Report, for the preparation of the message to Congress. Charles Pinkney was here a few minutes— Dr Watkins called, with a Letter from A. H. Tracy the former member of Congress from the Western part of the State of New-York; enquiring with great solicitude, whether I am, and also whether General Jackson is a Freemason. He says that it is circulated there with indefatigable assiduity that I am, and that he is
not a Mason— That the object of these Reports is to influence the elections; and that they do more powerfully operate upon it there than all other electioneering topics put together. About fifteen Months since a man by the name of William Morgan, published or attempted to publish at Batavia a Book professing to divulge the Secrets of Free Masonry— He was shortly afterwards kidnapped carried away—murdered, and thrown into lake Ontario, where his body has within a few days been found— No positive proof of his death had been till now produced; but as there has been ample evidence of a conspiracy among the freemasons, which succeeded in carrying him away, and had the purpose of destroying him, the consequence has been a universal excitement and popular fermentation in that vicinity which has extended throughout New-York, and has at length brought a mass of obloquy upon the Institution of Masonry itself— I told Watkins he might answer Tracy that I am not, and never was a Freemason—but whether General Jackson is or not I do not know. Mr Forrest brought an Exequatur which I signed for Elias Reed as Vice-Consul of Portugal, for the State of Georgia— Mr Clay was here— Had been yesterday and this day at the Races; which were poor— Mrs W. S. Smith went home— Mrs Adams still keeps her chamber, but is slowly recovering.
26. V:15.— Chronometer stopped— Walk before dinner.

This morning, as I was dressing, in the dark, standing by the table on which my Chronometer, made by French was laid, I perceived that it suddenly stopped. I had not touched it, nor has any violence happened to it from which I could account for this accident. My father once lost the Seal at arms, which he had used for many years and with which he had sealed the Treaties of Peace with Great Britain of November 1782. and September 1783— The Cornelian Stone had dropped from its golden setting— It was found the next day, and he told me that the loss of that Seal, had affected him more than so trifling an incident ought to have done— That Seal he afterwards gave me, and it is now in my possession— The stopping of my Chronometer this morning reminded me of my father’s remark upon the loss of his Seal— It affected me more than it ought to have— It was like the desertion of a friend upon whose fidelity you have leaned with unsuspecting confidence. My Chronometer is the first time piece, that I ever possessed upon which I could for any length of time depend— It now betrays my confidence, and I can take no true note of time—and what says the Moral?— “Lean not on Friendship or on Time.” Mrs Johnson came again this morning, and said there was a vacancy by the death of Mr Dyer, of a Clerkship in the Post-Office, and she intreated me to speak one word in favour of her husband to the Postmaster General, which I declined. Mr Anderson the Comptroller called while she was with me, but she then immediately withdrew. He said he came for a similar purpose of solicitation—in behalf of three persons—Joseph Wheaton—a Major Hamilton, heretofore Collector at Pensacola, and a Mr Tippett— Wheaton is superannuated, and almost starving— Hamilton complains of having been dismissed from his office without a hearing, and claims another by way of indemnity for his lost— Tippett’s pretensions rest chiefly upon their own antiquity— I had a further and long conversation with Mr Anderson upon general politicks— Mr Asbury Dickins brought and left with me a proof sheet of a circular Letter to be sent by him as Secretary to the Columbian Institute, soliciting correspondence, and contributions of seeds, plants, and specimens of animals, or minerals; to which is annexed a Report from a Committee of the Institute containing directions for the preservation, and transmission of specimens in the various branches of natural History. This procedure of the Institute corresponds with the project I am endeavouring to carry into execution of importing foreign useful plants for cultivation— I told Mr Dickins that I had not yet applied to the Columbian Institute for their aid to carry my plan into effect; because my first object was to procure some seeds and plants— If that shall be effected the co-operation of the Institute will become important, and then will be the time to call upon them, for their aid. Dickins himself will give all the assistance in his power— Mr Brent brought me back a remnant of blanks which I had left signed last Summer; at the Department of State, and which
have not been used. Judge Thruston came to solicit an appointment in the Marine Corps for one of his Sons. He complained that this Son had not received the appointment before, complained that too many appointments were given to foreigners, and that due attention was not paid in the distribution of Offices to natives, and to the families of revolutionary worthies— The judge himself holds under the Government a judicial Office for life— He has one Son a high salaried Clerk in the Department of State—and one Son an Officer in the army— These are in substance all lucrative Offices for life, and I intimated to the judge that I sometimes heard complaints, that too many places were accumulated in families— He felt the remark, and I told him that I should favour the application of his Son, as far as I could consistently with propriety.
27. V:15. Walk over the Tiber.

Mr Montandon is a watchmaker from Switzerland, whom Antoine found, and engaged to come and examine my Chronometer, and repair it if necessary— He took it out of its case, and immediately put it again in motion— The cause of its stoppage he told me was that a small portion of the oil used to lubricate the movement had exuded, and in the process of time became indurated, so as to intercept the motion of the balance— He said it would now go again as it had done, though possibly with less regularity and that in a few months it would need to be cleaned, and fresh oiled— Mr Wood is a traveller who resides in Frederic County Virginia— His visit was of mere curiosity. Mr Stockly was also a Virginian, from Accomack County, and brought a Letter of recommendation from Dr John S. Spence— He wishes to obtain an appointment as a Clerk in one of the Departments, and solicits my influence— Mr Southard was here, and spoke of the Navy Agency at Pensacola—of the Navy Commissioners—and of the Lieutenancy in the Marine Corps to be filled— Also of the promulgation of the Sentence of the Court Martial upon Coll. Smith of the Marines— Who is to be reprimanded in general Orders— I thought it would be sufficient to recite the Sentence of the Court, directing the reprimand; the approval of the President; and then simply to add, Coll. Smith is accordingly reprimanded— Mr Southard took with him, a Commission for Commission temporary for Commodore Rodgers that I had signed, and he took back a permanent Commission to Commodore Warrington, prepared for my signature; but erroneously dated in November last, before the advice and consent of the Senate had been given— Governor Duval, Dr Hannah, Mr Charles Pinkney, Coll. Trumbull and Dr Watkins— Coll. Trumbull brought with him a wooden model of a plan for Stair cases at the Capitol leading from the East and West fronts of the building to the Halls of the Senate and House of Representatives. By four flights of winding Stairs, each forming a quarter of a Circle; and leaving space for Rooms to deposit papers in between the massive columns— This plan is commendable both for its simplicity and elegance, and he says would cost 20,000 dollars. Mrs Smith was here and returned home in the Evening. I transplanted my two Apple trees, from the Pots in which they had been raised to the Garden. And planted 25 white oak acorns, and three walnuts in the same row of the Eastern bed, with the Battleground Acorns.
28. V:15. Sun rose 6:45—

Attended with Abigail Adams at the Unitarian Church this morning and heard Mr Motte, from Ephesians 2.8. “By grace are ye saved”— The discourse was divided into two parts, considering the words of the text with reference first to grace,and secondly to salvation— The doctrine was
Anti-Calvinistic, but rather declamatory than argumentative. The preacher left out from his text the greater part of the verse, of which it forms a part, and that upon which the Calvinists chiefly rely—the whole verse is [“]For by grace are ye saved through faith; and that not of yourselves: it is the gift of God[”]— To meet the argument of the Calvinists the whole verse must be taken, and to answer it, the context of the whole chapter, and the purpose of the whole Epistle should be discussed. The Epistle to the Ephesians, written by Paul when a prisoner at Rome, consists itself of two parts: The first closing with the third chapter, where there would seem to be a formal termination of the Epistle— It begins by blessing God, that from before the foundation of the world he had predestinated Us that is Paul himself and the Ephesians, to enjoy the blessings of Christianity, by their faith in Christ and their practice of his moral precepts— But Paul was a Jew, of the seed of Abraham, the elect of God, and the Ephesians had been Gentiles, without hope and without God in the world— The object therefore of the first half of the Epistle is to convince them, that by the special favour of God, preordained before the creation of the world, Jews and Gentiles were all included in the purpose of salvation, and destined to the blessings of immortality, by their common faith in Christ, and the performance of good works taught by him, and to which they were in like manner fore ordained— To this course of reasoning, chiefly concentrated in the second Chapter, the verse from which Mr Motte took his text belongs— The tenor of the Epistle countenances the doctrines of Election and Predestination, but it urges a predestination of good works, and the last three chapters of it are devoted entirely to the inculcation of morality in the various relations of human life— How it is possible to reconcile the principle of predestination with the use or efficacy of prayer I know not; but it is vain to deny that the Epistles of Paul, and this to the Ephesians in particular lay down the doctrine of predestination, in the most unqualified terms: enjoining at the same time with equal earnestness the practice of fervent prayer, and the performance of good works— In the afternoon I heard from Mr Baker an exposition of the first Psalm. I did not attend Church this Evening, having past the last night almost sleepless. I had a visit at noon from the brothers Vail; who informed me that Dr. Lovell had returned from Govr Barbour’s, and that the Governor’s Child was convalescent— I applied this morning by advice of Dr Huntt, the lunar Caustic to the callous on the forefinger of my right hand. Received and answered a Letter from my Son George.
29. VI:15. By day-light.

I slept upwards of an hour later than usual this morning; and thereby lost a useful portion of the day. Mr Black brought me the Chart of the Coast from New-York to St. Augustine which I had promised to take. Dr Hannah informed me that he should go the day after to morrow for New-York; and asked me for the Letters of introduction to my friends there; which to a person so much a stranger to me I did not incline to give. Mr Pleasonton brought a number of recommendations for the appointment of keepers to several new Light-houses— Mr Clay took back the draft of Instructions to William Tudor, as Charge d’Affaires at the Court of Rio de Janeiro, which he had sent me and I had read and approved. He said also that the friends of the Administration in Kentucky, were taking measures for acting in concert at the elections of the next year, and that he had received an application from a Committee asking whether I should be willing to receive from them, and answer certain direct enquiries, in relation to my public accounts, and also relating to my conduct as a member of the Senate, upon the acquisition of Louisiana— He observed that the misrepresentations with regard to my accounts, which had been circulated from Speeches in Congress, and in the newspapers, had been of the most pernicious influence upon the late Elections in Kentucky— I told him, that I was aware of the uses which had been made and were making of these misrepresentations; but that
I did not think there would be a propriety in my corresponding with an electioneering Committee on these Subjects. I was aware that it is the usage in Kentucky for Candidates to Offices conferred by the suffrages of the People to offer themselves and solicit votes—a natural consequence of which is that they are called to account before the people, and to answer any charges against them, or enquiries made of them respecting their conduct or principles. But this has not been customary with reference to the Office of President of the United States, and I should not be willing to set the Precedent. As to my accounts, I had partly prepared a statement of them to be laid before Congress at the next or the succeeding Session— This appeared to me the most proper manner of exhibiting the facts to the public—and the Congressional documents will shew my conduct in relation to the purchase of Louisiana— Mr Brent came to enquire for the recommendations, on the last Appointment of a judge in the Territory of Michigan— Dr Mease has brought with him his manuscript manual for raising Silk-worms and the manufacture of silk; prepared by direction of the Secretary of the Treasury in compliance with a Resolution of the House of Representatives— He had promised to deliver it, before the first of November, and has brought it accordingly— But he wishes to add a few notes upon the process of dyeing silk collected from French Treatises recently received, and Mr Rush not being yet quite ready to examine the Book the Doctor is to take it back, and send it again in ten days— Mr Southard brought with him, and we went over all the recommendations for a Navy Agent at Pensacola, and I desired him to prepare a Commission for Nathanael Amory. He left with me a written argument of Richard S. Coxe of Georgetown in behalf of a claim of Salary to two pursers in the Navy—Spence and Pottinger— He spoke also of the appointment of a Lieutenant in the Marine Corps; and I told him I inclined in favour of Judge Thruston’sSon— Mr Persico the Sculptor came and reported progress of his work on the Pediment of the Capitol— I spoke to him about a bust for the monument of my father, which he said he would undertake when his engagement at the Capitol should be completed. Dr Mease, and Mrs W. S. Smith dined with us; and the Doctor told me much of Dr Bancroft; of his Book upon permanent Colours—his patent for Quercitron Bark; set aside upon a trial in a Court of Law: of his Sons; and of his last visit to this Country in 1809. I had intended to go into the woods this morning with John, but was detained at home by visitors till near five O’Clock, and could only take a half an hour’s walk before dinner— In the last five days I have signed 733 and 4. Land-grants.

I sent for Mr Bulfinch this morning, and spoke with him of a furnace to be put up in the President’s House, like those under the Rotunda, at the Capitol— Marden has finished his work and is gone— But the maker of the Stoves is a Mr Daniel Safford of Boston; to whom I wrote, requesting him to send one here as soon as possible and a man to put it up— Mr Matthews the Roman Catholic Priest came for a contribution that I had promised for a school of the Sisters of Charity— He pronounced a high Eulogium upon this Institution, which he said Buonaparte had preserved in France, though he had abolished all the other Religious Orders— But these he said were incarnate Angels— Mr Armstrong the Ex-Consul at St. Domingo, and Mr Clark of South Carolina came together. Mr Forrest brought me the part of the new Register to be published which contains the names of the persons employed in the Department of State. Governor Barbour was here—just returned from his
Seat in Virginia. His child is recovering. He recommended Christian Tarr, for Superintendent of the continuation of Cumberland Road, in the place of Mr Ewing deceased—and I agreed to the appointment. Mr Joseph Gales, Mayor of the City, called with Mr Ide, one of the publishers of a newspaper in Vermont— Mr Gales left with me a Resolution of the Boards of Aldermen and of Common Council, for raising by Lottery the sum of 10.000 dollars, for establishing and endowing public Schools, and for erecting a Town House or City Hall, in the City of Washington. Which requires the approbation of the President of the United States— Also a request for my decision, upon the laying of the pavement on the North side of the Square, North of the President’s House— The Commissioner of the Public Buildings, having in my absence, commenced laying the pavement two feet narrower than the adjoining Squares, but suspended the work at the request of the Citizens interested in the neighbouring property, for my decision— He spoke also of a Resolution of the Corporation which was sent me last year, soliciting an allowance from the funds of the U.S. of 500 dollars a year; towards the Salary of a City Surveyor—with which, although I thought the request reasonable and proper, I had declined complying, from a doubt of my authority legally to do so— I told Mr Gales I would look into the subject again, but believed I should continue doubtful of my power— He said he would consider it as so settled, and that the Corporation would apply to Congress— He added that the necessity for a regular and responsible City Surveyor was indispensable; and that for the want of such an Officer confusion was already creeping into the location of new buildings— It had been only last week discovered that a house the building of which had cost six thousand dollars encroached eight feet upon the Street— Mr Calvert and S. H. Smith paid friendly morning visits— Mr Rush had an hour’s conversation with me concerning the preparation of his annual Report on the finances. He proposes introducing into it collateral views of political Economy, more than has been done by any of his Predecessors since Hamilton— He concurred with me in the marked superiority of Hamilton’s Reports over those of his Successors; his own, form the first exceptions, and his intention is that the next shall be still more distinguished by a discussion of principles and deduction of consequences applicable to the revenue— He also promised me in about ten days the minutes from the Treasury necessary for the preparation of the Message. I had intended to go into the woods to gather Acorns at one O’Clock; but was detained by visitors till near three; and had scarcely got upon the ground when there came up a heavy shower which drenched me with rain, and drove me home so wet that I found a complete change of cloathing necessary. I visited however the Rock Creek Church Yard, and there saw the tombs of my wife’s mother Mrs Catherine Johnson, of Walter Hellen, and of his first wife Mrs Adams’seldest Sister. They all died while we were last in Europe; and the sight of the Stones which cover their remains awakened in my mind many affecting recollections, and admonished me, to be also ready— I gathered a few very fine white Oak Acorns, all of which had sprouted, and the taproots of some of which had already taken hold of the ground— Mrs Smith spent the day here; but went home in the Evening.

My Chronometer stopped again a few minutes before I rose this morning, but on a slight shaking resumed its movements— Mr Gurley brought me a Letter from Charles Coffin, President of the College of East Tennessee; recommending John A. M’Kinney for the appointment of U.S. District Attorney for East Tennessee, in the place of Pryor Lea, elected to Congress— Mr Forrest brought me the manuscript Statements from the Departments of War and the Navy; made up for the Register next to be published— Benjamin Stoddert Ewell a youth of seventeen years of age, brought me a Letter from his mother, soliciting for him
an appointment of Cadet at West Point. He said application had already been made for him at the War Department two or three years since. I advised him to apply again, and told him I would speak to the Secretary of War in his behalf— Captain M’Neill and Lieutenant Monroe called together— M’Neill, has just returned from the Survey of the Road for the Baltimore and Ohio Railway which he says is unquestionably practicable— Lieutt Monroe is going with his wife to old Point comfort, where he is stationed. Governor Barbour called merely to introduce Dr Semple, who is acting as President of the Trustees of the extinct Columbia College He gave me an account of the late proceedings of that board, and the substance of his observations was a proposal that the creditors of the College should hold a meeting and agree to receive a per Centage upon their demands, and give the College a discharge— I told him that if such a meeting should be held, I would authorise some person to appear at it for me and to agree to any thing which the other creditors shall think reasonable; but that I thought some specific offer should be made by the Trustees of the College, upon which the Creditors in accepting it might depend— He said they could give no pledge; as their means of payment must depend upon their collection of the subscriptions— He spoke of the mismanagement of the pecuniary concerns of the Institution by Mr Rice and Mr Brown— But observed they were withdrawn from it— That they had now a more efficient board of Trustees; and had employed efficient men to collect their subscriptions North and South— But his encouragement is all in general terms, and his exposition of the state of their affairs presents no other object to my mind, than that of absolute and total insolvency— I find little satisfaction in looking forward— Johnson Hellen and John went this day to Rockville— I signed a Commission to Nathanael Amory as Navy Agent at Pensacola— I planted in the Southern seedling bed, eight rows of alternate white Oak Acorns Shellbarks and black Walnuts with two Chesnuts that I found in the woods yesterday.

Day. The first half of this month, was consumed in travelling from Quincy to this place— That life is always irregular, and especially interferes with my habit of daily writing— Its next consequence is to produce an arrearage of my diary, and at the same time an accumulation of matters to be recorded— It is impossible to write in Stages; and so difficult in Steamboats that I scarcely ever attempt it. At Taverns it is not much more easy— Even at home, whether in Quincy or here; the day is so constantly absorbed by visitors or business that I have only the morning before breakfast and the evening after dinner for writing— On my return to this place my Diary was a full fortnight in arrears; but I had kept the minutes for it without intermission— It was three days after my return, before I recovered the regular course of my occupations; but during the last twelve days I have written a morning and an Evening page in this Book, and I am at this moment bringing up the last Lines of arrears— To accomplish this however I have been obliged to suspend my morning walks and thus to intrench upon the regularity of my daily exercise. This must be restored; and as the Session of Congress approaches I must expect interruptions of visitors in the Evening as well as in the day. I bless the giver of Good that my health continues to improve; and deeply mourn that my wife’s appears to decline, and becomes more and more alarming. The heart knoweth its own bitterness, and a stranger intermeddleth not with its joys— I ought this day to have begun upon the draft of my Message, for the Commencement of the first Session of the 20th Congress; but postpone a painful task to the last moment.
